ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Approaches to synthesize target molecules with different type of reaction, especially the stereochemistry and regioselectivity. Comparisons between different methods for both commercial applications and academic usages.
I gained knowledge about synthetic methods in organic chemistry. Pretty much exactly what it says on the tin.

Knowledge of stereospecific and stereoselective transformations, organometallic reactions, catalytic cycles, mechanistic considerations for a reaction, and survey of current/modern reactions in the literature.
A proper basis for synthetic organic chemistry
An understanding of the methods commonly used in pharma, natural products synthesis, mass production, and drug discovery to synthesize molecules. Breadth and depth were well balanced.
Pretty cool insights into organometallics

I developed a lot more insight on how to think about reactions and how they can be used to create helpful intermediates, instead of just going from A to B, there are more creative ways to get from A to B with the stereochem i want.
I learned various new reactions and all of the ways to optimize them according to your substrate and desired product.
I was able to expand upon the concepts learned previously to understand even more reactions.

I gained a better understanding of the important methods in modern organic synthesis. Professor Ellman dove deep into important methodological considerations including methodology, scope, and application.
I learned so much in this course. Very happy with how it was taught.
This was a fantastic course about advanced synthetic chemistry methods. In a very organized and clear way, Professor Ellman guided us through some of the most important chemistry reactions.
I learned many synthetic methods and gradually developed skills on evaluating each strategies before applying them.
Application and mechanistic insight into synthetic methods frequently used in research and industry

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: The knowledge is clear and organized.
Weakness: The chalk is producing large dust when using. Dust-free chalk is recommended.

Lectures were well paced, lectures were given at reasonable speeds (mostly) and psets were aligned well with content covered in the lecture. The overall pacing of the class could be improved, however, as we ran out of time for our final pset, and there were many lectures late in the semester that seemed to go faster than the earlier lectures, which is perhaps the opposite pacing you'd want in the finals period. Also, pset feedback and answer keys could be written more clearly.
The material is taught by an extremely knowledgable professor and he makes it very accessible for someone interested in organic chemistry.

By nature of the content, it can sometimes be a flood of information. The course overall sets you up to learn new synthetic chemistry well and begin thinking about issues in the routes to synthesizing desired compounds.

Strengths -- Ellman, his knowledge, psets did a great job of preparing you for exams, good mixture of breadth and depth

Weaknesses -- almost none, the only suggestion I can think of is that sometimes when a stereoselective reaction is drawn, it is unclear which isomer of the catalyst leads to which isomer of the product and isomers are vary rarely noted as R or S during lectures, so I think being more specific about which isomer is which and naming them would be helpful for clarity. Otherwise I think explanations of stereochemical rationale are excellent
The straight lecture style wasnt super engaging. I think a couple pauses for audience participation would be warranted
Lecture and homework correlated very well but it could be more engaging in lecture.

I enjoy how in depth the class goes and the problem sets are very useful with real-world applications. I wish that maybe the class went a little bit faster so we could learn more and finish all the topics listed on the syllabus.
The Professor could pause more after he says Does that make sense to everybody so that people have a chance to respond.
Very organized and good workload.

This course is extremely well organized and Professor Ellman teaches it in an extremely clear way. I enjoyed the weekly problem sets very much as they allowed me to consolidate the knowledge learned in class. I also appreciated the references to scientific literature in this course. I will surely refer to them during my graduate studies.
This course is great: highly organized with clearcut lectures.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes I would. This course is a great approach to learn different synthetic skills that can really be applied into research. I recommend anyone who is working on organic chemistry or organic related areas (such as polymer chemistry, organometallics) to take this course.

I would recommend this course to any chem major needing an advanced chem elective credit. It's not terribly difficult if you have a solid background in organic and inorganic chem. Inorganic chem helps a LOT for the second half of the semester, as there are a lot of transition metal catalyzed mechanisms that you'll have to go through, so if possible, I'd recommend taking some courses on transition metal chemistry/organometallic chemistry before this course.
Yes! Any student interested in Organic chemistry has to take this course. It's too valuable in content and extremely well taught.
Certainly, if one has any interest in organic synthesis, Prof Ellman is a great place to start.
Maybe. If they like orgo
Yes, it will be really helpful in my research and helps build base knowledge of reactions and organic chemistry

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in pursuing a career in organic chemistry as it goes through the fundamental reactions necessary to begin thinking about methodology and total synthesis projects.
I would only recommend to those pursing the Chemistry major, as it is a graduate level class.
Yes. Essential course for anyone interested in pursuing organic chemistry.
Yes, it was excellent, for a grad or undergrad. I highly recommend. I learned so much and can walk away with a lot of new knowledge.

Yes, absolutely! I think this course should be taken by all first-year organic chemistry graduate students. Professor Ellman is a fantastic teacher and, with this course, he is helping us gain confidence in our organic chemistry skills.
Yes I will. This course is important for first-year organic graduate students to develop their understanding of synthesis.
